  • Element
org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.udf

Annotation Type UDFType


  • @InterfaceAudience.Public
 @InterfaceStability.Evolving
 @Target(value=TYPE)
 @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
 @Inherited
public @interface UDFType
    UDFType annotations are used to describe properties of a UDF. This gives important information to the optimizer. If the UDF is not deterministic, or if it is stateful, it is necessary to annotate it as such for correctness.

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      boolean commutative
      Whether result of this operation will be altered by reordering its children.
      boolean deterministic
      Certain optimizations should not be applied if UDF is not deterministic.
      boolean distinctLike
      A UDF is considered distinctLike if the UDF can be evaluated on just the distinct values of a column.
      boolean impliesOrder
      Using in analytical functions to specify that UDF implies an ordering
      boolean runtimeConstant
      Property used to mark functions like current_timestamp, current_date, current_database().
      boolean stateful
      If a UDF stores state based on the sequence of records it has processed, it is stateful.

    • Element Detail

      • deterministic

        public abstract boolean deterministic
        Certain optimizations should not be applied if UDF is not deterministic. Deterministic UDF returns same result each time it is invoked with a particular input. This determinism just needs to hold within the context of a query.
        Returns:
        true if the UDF is deterministic
        Default:
        true

      • stateful

        public abstract boolean stateful
        If a UDF stores state based on the sequence of records it has processed, it is stateful. A stateful UDF cannot be used in certain expressions such as case statement and certain optimizations such as AND/OR short circuiting don't apply for such UDFs, as they need to be invoked for each record. row_sequence is an example of stateful UDF. A stateful UDF is considered to be non-deterministic, irrespective of what deterministic() returns.
        Returns:
        true
        Default:
        false

      • runtimeConstant

        public abstract boolean runtimeConstant
        Property used to mark functions like current_timestamp, current_date, current_database(). These functions aren't actually deterministic (the values can change between queries), but the value returned by these functions should be consistent for the life of the query, so constant folding still applies for these functions. Queries using these functions should not be eligible for materialized views or query caching.
        Returns:
        true if the function is a runtime constant
        Default:
        false

      • distinctLike

        public abstract boolean distinctLike
        A UDF is considered distinctLike if the UDF can be evaluated on just the distinct values of a column. Examples include min and max UDFs. This information is used by metadata-only optimizer.
        Returns:
        true if UDF is distinctLike
        Default:
        false

      • impliesOrder

        public abstract boolean impliesOrder
        Using in analytical functions to specify that UDF implies an ordering
        Returns:
        true if the function implies order
        Default:
        false

      • commutative

        public abstract boolean commutative
        Whether result of this operation will be altered by reordering its children.
        Returns:
        true if commutative law applies to this function
        Default:
        false
